userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Remember you are  a whole person -- focus on mental, physical, emotional, etc. Nutrition response testing, VSL3 (probiotic), eliminate food triggers, mind-body stress reduction... do your own research!

userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Take your diet very seriously.  Understand what triggers flares by keeping a food diary and consider an elimination diet.  Reducing/eliminating gluten (wheat, oats, etc.) and dairy can have a significant impact.  The Paleo Diet, particularly the Anti-Inflammatory Paleo Diet, might be worth considering.  Supplements can also be important, particularly Vitamin D, Folic Acid and B12.  Other supplements worth considering include Alpha Lipoic Acid (ALA), Conjugated Linoleic Acid (CLA), Vitamin C, concentrated mineral drops, liquid calcium citrate, and more.  Probiotics can be hit or miss.  Typically people with ulcerative colitis benefit more from probiotics than people with Crohn's.  Supplements to boost energy may also be beneficial, such as the supplements used to treat chronic fatigue syndrome.  Get plenty of sleep and reduce stress.  Exercise is also particularly important for imroving health and mood.  Yoga has helped many people too.

userStories.tip: Diet, Supplements, Exercise, Yoga, Stress Reduction

condition.description:
Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the digestive system. It is one of a group of diseases called inflammatory bowel disease. Crohn's can affect any area from the mouth to the anus. It often affects the lower part of the small intestine called the ileum.

The cause of Crohn's disease is unknown. It may be due to an abnormal reaction by the body's immune system. It also seems to run in some families. It most commonly starts between the ages of 13 and 30.

The most common symptoms are pain in the abdomen and diarrhea. Other symptoms include

  • Bleeding from the rectum
  • Weight loss
  • Fever

Your doctor will diagnose Crohn's disease with a physical exam, lab tests, imaging tests, and a colonoscopy.

Crohn's can cause complications, such as intestinal blockages, ulcers in the intestine, and problems getting enough nutrients. People with Crohn's can also have joint pain and skin problems. Children with the disease may have growth problems.

There is no cure for Crohn's. Treatment can help control symptoms, and may include medicines, nutrition supplements, and/or surgery. Some people have long periods of remission, when they are free of symptoms.

NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

carousel_items: Take Budesonide with meals to avoid upsetting your stomach.
Eating smaller, more frequent meals and drinking plenty of fluids is helpful while taking Budesonide.
Be sure to take Budesonide at the same time every day.
Don't eat or drink grapefruit while taking Budesonide since it can interfere with how the medication works.
Can't be used long-term.
Don't stop taking this medicine suddenly, but work with your doctor to slowly decrease the amount you take to avoid unwanted side effects.
Let your doctor know about any night sweating, unexplained fevers, or infections that won't get better.

basics.benefits_moa: Budesonide is a corticosteroid. It reduces the inflammation in your intestines by blocking the proteins that trigger inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Budesonide helps treat Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, but you can’t take it for long because of its serious side effects.
downsides: Many people decide to stop taking Budesonide because of its side effects.
Budesonide isn't recommended for long-term treatment.
You can’t drink alcohol while taking Budesonide.
Taking corticosteroids like Budesonide can make it hard for your body to fight infections.
Budesonide can pass into breast milk if you're nursing.

upsides: Budesonide works for 50-70% of people with mild to moderate Crohn’s disease.
Budesonide is preferred over Prednisone for treating people with Crohn’s disease.
Causes fewer side effects than other corticosteroids.
Low doses of Budesonide can be used for a few weeks or even a few months to achieve remission.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur when taking Budesonide. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extremely low energy, and depression. Changes in your Budesonide dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop your medication.

risks_warnings.title: Steroid use
risks_warnings.description: People who are switching from strong glucocorticosteroid treatment to weak glucocorticosteroid treatment like Budesonide can have symptoms of steroid withdrawal. These effects include adrenal suppression and adrenal crisis, which include symptoms of joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy, low blood pressure, fever, confusion, and depression.

Take it exactly as your doctor prescribed.
Take with food to decrease stomach upset.
Can cause trouble sleeping. Take in the morning or 2-3 hours before bed if more than one dose is needed.
Can cause changes in mood, blood pressure, blood sugar, and water retention.
You should check your blood pressure and blood sugar when taking this medicine if you already have high blood pressure or diabetes.
A taper is often needed to stop the medicine, especially if you've been on it for more than 1 week.

basics.benefits_moa: Medrol is a corticosteroid that's similar to what your body naturally makes. It reduces swelling and other immune responses that can cause you pain, discomfort, or harm.
basics.bottom_line: Medrol is corticosteroid available in many forms (oral, injectable) that's great for controlling the unwanted symptoms from your immune responses and will make you feel better. There are lots of side effects but most of are tolerable or can be managed.
downsides: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Medrol.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Medrol too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Medrol dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: It’s rare, but taking Medrol for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Medrol and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: Medrol may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye.  Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Medrol may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Medrol can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Medrol can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Medrol if your pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma). If you're taking Medrol to treat an autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis or for antirejection treatment after a transplant, there are disease registries that you'll need to contact so make sure you talk to your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Medrol increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers
Taking Medrol with other medicine that can cause stomach problems

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Medrol for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Medrol. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Medrol if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

Taking antacids with Mesalamine can make your inflammation worse. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes.
You can sunburn more easily when taking Mesalamine. Use sunscreen and protective clothing when you go outdoors.
Don't break, chew, or crush the tablets because they're coated and won't work as well.
The suppositories should be kept in for at least 1 to 3 hours to get the most benefit.

basics.benefits_moa: Mesalamine is an anti-inflammatory medication. Researchers don't know exactly how Mesalamine works in the colon, but it seems to lower the chemicals in the body that cause inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Mesalamine is an effective first-line medicine for inflammatory bowel disease. There isn't a generic version and you'll have to take it multiple times a day.
downsides: No generic versions are available for the tablets, capsules, and suppositories (meaning it could be somewhat expensive).
Doesn't work well for severe colon inflammation.
You may need to take Mesalamine three or four times a day.
Not a good option if you have kidney disease.

Available in tablets, capsules, enemas, and suppositories.
Certain forms of Mesalamine can be used during pregnancy. Talk to your doctor if you're pregnant, or plan on becoming pregnant, and you want to take Mesalamine.

risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breathe or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Mesalamine and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor right away.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening kidney or liver function
risks_warnings.description: Mesalamine is broken down by the kidney and liver. If you have kidney or liver problems, talk to your doctor because you may need to take a different dose of the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away.

risks_warnings.title: Liver toxicity
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Mesalamine can cause liver injury, hepatitis, and liver failure. Let your doctor know and get medical attention if you notice yellowing skin or eyes.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening of colitis
risks_warnings.description: Mesalamine can cause colitis-like symptoms in some people when they start treatment. It’s noted with Asacol HD, but it can happen with other products. If you've started taking Mesalamine and have cramps, belly pain, bloody diarrhea, with or without fever, headache, weakness, rash, or eye inflammation, let your doctor know right away. You'll need to switch to another medicine. These symptoms should go away once Asacol HD tablets are stopped.

basics.benefits_moa: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic. It kills bacteria by preventing them from reproducing and repairing themselves.
basics.bottom_line: Ciprofloxacin is a good and cheap antibiotic to treat many types of bacterial infections. However, you have to reduce your caffeine intake, and have to protect yourself from the sun.
downsides: Must be used with caution in people over 60 years of age, or who have had either an organ transplant or on long-term steroid use due to possible tendon rupture.
If you have caffeine while on Ciprofloxacin, you may noticed increased effects of the caffeine.
Ciprofloxacin can make your skin more sensitive to the sun.
Can't be used if you've ever had myasthenia gravis.

carousel_items: Don't drink any alcohol while on this (and don't even use mouthwash with alcohol in it) for at least 3 days after using Metronidazole since it can cause a serious reaction in your stomach and make you throw up.
Take this medication exactly as your doctor or pharmacist tells you. Don't stop taking it early, or the bacteria left in your body will become resistant to future antibiotics you'll take.
If you're taking the extended release (ER) form, take it 1 hour before or 2 hours after you eat.

basics.benefits_moa: Metronidazole is an antibiotic that kills bacteria by cutting off their supply of energy and ruining their DNA.
basics.bottom_line: Metronidazole is a very good way to treat certain bacteria infections, but you can't have any alcohol while on it since it'll make you throw up. A lot.
downsides: You can't drink alcohol while on this medication, and for at least 3 days after you finish Metronidazole.
If you're breastfeeding, you'll need to switch to a formula to feed your baby for at least 3 days after you finish taking Metronidazole.
Side effects include nausea, constipation, diarrhea, and headache.
Your urine can turn a dark red color while on Metronidazole.
The oral version of Flagyl 375 mg is only available as brand name so this particular form can be expensive.

upsides: Metronidazole is extremely effective in killing bacteria.
Unlike many other antibiotics, Metronidazole is less likely to make bacteria resistant to the medication.
Available in different forms including a topical (skin) version, a vaginal version, and multiple oral (by mouth) versions.
Most forms are available as a generic, so it is relatively cheap.

carousel_items_processed.orig: Don't drink any alcohol while on this (and don't even use mouthwash with alcohol in it) for at least 3 days after using Metronidazole since it can cause a serious reaction in your stomach and make you throw up.
Take this medication exactly as your doctor or pharmacist tells you. Don't stop taking it early, or the bacteria left in your body will become resistant to future antibiotics you'll take.
If you're taking the extended release (ER) form, take it 1 hour before or 2 hours after you eat.

risks_warnings.title: Changes in mental status | Nerve damage
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people on Metronidazole who have had changes in their mental status or suffered nerve damage. This is rare, and usually goes away after Metronidazole is stopped. Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly feel confused, have trouble walking, feel dizzy, or feel numbness or tingling.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of people on Metronidazole who have had changes in their mental status or suffered nerve damage. This is rare, and usually goes away after Metronidazole is stopped. Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly feel confused, have trouble walking, feel dizzy, or feel numbness or tingling.

risks_warnings.title: Aseptic meningitis
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people on Metronidazole who have had aseptic meningitis, or an inflammation along the coverings of the brain. This is extremely rare. Call your doctor immediately if you have a very painful headache, sensitivity to light, loss of appetite or vomiting once you start taking Metronidazole.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of people on Metronidazole who have had aseptic meningitis, or an inflammation along the coverings of the brain. This is extremely rare. Call your doctor immediately if you have a very painful headache, sensitivity to light, loss of appetite or vomiting once you start taking Metronidazole.

risks_warnings.title: Cancer
risks_warnings.description: Clinical studies involving mice and rats have shown that exposure to Metronidazole can cause cancer in these animals. However, studies haven't shown that this is true in humans, but Metronidazole should only be given when your doctor thinks it's necessary.

carousel_items: Cimzia is a medicine that's injected just under the skin (subcutaneous). It can be given in your doctor's office or you can do it yourself at home.
It can take multiple doses before you start to see any effects, so don't change your dose without talking to your doctor.
Tell your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.
You'll need to have a TB (tuberculosis) test before you start Cimzia and periodically during treatment.
Don't get any live vaccines while you're taking Cimzia since they may not work as well. Wait at least 3 months after you've stopped taking Cimzia before getting a live vaccine.

basics.benefits_moa: Cimzia is a monoclonal antibody. It lowers inflammation in the body by blocking a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor).
basics.bottom_line: Cimzia is an effective medicine to calm down your immune system, but it can be expensive and it requires a lot of monitoring while you're taking it.
downsides: Can lower your immune system's ability to fight infections. You can get serious infections such as TB (tuberculosis) and infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria.
Can have a higher risk for causing bladder infections, rash, and upper respiratory infections (cold or flu) compared to other similar medicines.
Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers.
Requires routine tests to check for infections.
Not a good choice if you have a history of heart failure, nervous system problems, or hepatitis B.
There's no generic available and it can be very expensive.

upsides: In studies, people with RA (rheumatoid arthritis) taking methotrexate had improved symptoms when Cimzia was added to methotrexate.
Cimzia is as effective as other similar medicines for Crohn's disease. It can be an option for people taking other RA medications that have too many side effects of don't work anymore.
Cimzia lasts longer in the body than other RA medications, letting it work longer.
Available in a prefilled syringe. This can make it easier to give yourself the injection.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Cimzia can increase the risk for developing serious infections, such as TB (tuberculosis) or infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria. These can be life-threatening, so call your doctor right away if you develop a serious infection or a blood infection.
risk_factors: Medications that lower immune system function

description_processed.orig: Cimzia can increase the risk for developing serious infections, such as TB (tuberculosis) or infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria. These can be life-threatening, so call your doctor right away if you develop a serious infection or a blood infection.

risks_warnings.title: Cancer
risks_warnings.description: Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers. Talk to your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.

description_processed.orig: Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers. Talk to your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.

risks_warnings.title: Tuberculosis | Hepatitis B
risks_warnings.description: You'll need to have a TB (tuberculosis) test before you start Cimzia and periodically during treatment. You should treat latent TB before starting Cimzia. If you're a carrier of HBV (hepatitis B virus), taking Cimzia can cause reactivation of the virus. You'll need routine tests during and after treatment with Cimzia.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Cimzia can cause serious allergic reactions and life-threatening organ failure. Report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Heart failure
risks_warnings.description: Cimzia can worsen heart failure or cause new heart failure. Talk to your doctor if you have a history of heart failure.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders

carousel_items: Humira is a medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous). Your doctor can give you your first dose, then let you self-inject it once so you learn how to do it correctly.
Humira lowers the your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you come down with a fever, cough, or notice flu-like symptoms.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start using Humira.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex since the syringe needle cover has latex in it.
Don't inject Humira into skin that's red, bruised, or irritated. Rotate your injection areas to avoid skin reactions.
As with all injection medicines, store away from children and throw used syringes away in a protective container, and not in the trash.

basics.benefits_moa: Humira is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Humira is very effective at calming down your immune system, but it's expensive, you have to take into account the hassle of injections and traveling with the medication.
downsides: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Humira lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.

You're first dose of Humira will need to be given at your doctor's office. If you decide not to self-inject and don't have someone to do it for you, you'll need to continue to see your doctor for each dose.
You'll need to properly dispose of the needle, syringes, or Pen in a special (FDA-approved) sharps container.
Because it needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

downsides_processed.orig: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Because it needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Most people feel it's worth the hassle.
Once you've learned the correct way to use Humira, you can inject the medicine yourself without going to your doctor's office.
It's available in a single-use pen (Humira Pen) that may be more convenient and easier for some people to use.
It's an alternative for people with Crohn's disease who stopped getting better on other TNF-blockers or had side effects that made them switch.

When you take the Humira out of the fridge, hold it under your arm for 10 minutes or so to let it war to room temperature-it stings a lot less.

carousel_items_processed.orig: Humira is a medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous). Your doctor can give you your first dose, then let you self-inject it once so you learn how to do it correctly.
Humira lowers the your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you come down with a fever, cough, or notice flu-like symptoms.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start using Humira.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex since the syringe needle cover has latex in it.
Don't inject Humira into skin that's red, bruised, or irritated. Rotate your injection areas to avoid skin reactions.
As with all injection medicines, store away from children and throw used syringes away in a protective container, and not in the trash.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Humira has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Humira has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Humira may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Humira is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Humira may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Humira can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Humira. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Humira works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Humira.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Humira works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Humira.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Humira can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while your taking Humira since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

carousel_items: Stelara is an immunosuppressant medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous).
Your doctor will give your first dose then let you self-inject once you learn how to do it correctly.
It's very important you read the Medication Guide especially if you're giving yourself injections.
Usual dosing to build up the medicine in your body is a starting dose, then 4 weeks, then 12 weeks. Maintenance dosing is every 12 weeks.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start injecting Stelara.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex. The prefilled syringe needle cover contains a latex product.
Don't use/inject if the medicine contains any particles or is discolored.
Rotate your injection areas using front of the thigh, outer area of upper arms or lower part of your belly (not around belly button). Don't inject into skin that's red, bruised or irritated.
Stelara can increase your risk of common infections, reactivate infections hidden in your body, and in some people, cause rare infections.
Serious and life-threatening nervous system and allergic reactions can happen immediately, days or months after starting Stelara. Stelara can increase your risk of certain skin cancer.
Dispose of used syringes in a protective (Sharps) container. DON'T throw in the trash.
Don't get any live vaccines while you're taking Stelara. If you need to get a vaccine, ask your doctor first.

basics.benefits_moa: Stelara is a biologic response modifier, or biologic. It blocks two immune system proteins called IL-12 and IL-23. This slows down new skin cell formation, and lowers inflammation for people with psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Stelara works for two psoriatic conditions. It may be somewhat of a hassle because of the injection, but after the first two doses, you only need to take it every 12 weeks.
downsides: It's an injection.

Stelara lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
You have to get your first dose of Stelara at your doctor's office. If you decide not to self-inject and don't have someone to do it for you, you'll need to continue to see your doctor for each dose.
You'll need to properly dispose of the needle and syringes in a special (FDA-approved) sharps container.
Because Stelara needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

upsides: Stelara works throughout your whole body (systemic therapy) and may be better than just applying medicine to your skin (local therapy) for moderate or severe plaque psoriasis that covers large areas or many areas of your body.
It's used alone or together with another medicine called methotrexate for better results to treat active psoriatic arthritis.
Initial dosing might be a hassle, but then you only have to take it every 12 weeks.
People treated with Stelara for psoriatic arthritis felt better and had more physical improvement compared to not using the medicine (placebo).

risks_warnings.title: Serious Infections
risks_warnings.description: Stelara can increase your risk of serious bacterial, fungal and viral infections.  In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Stelara. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash, tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Stelara can increase your risk of serious bacterial, fungal and viral infections. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash, tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Possible infections
risks_warnings.description: People who lack proteins IL12 and IL23 are at higher risk for nontuberculous,  certain types of salmonella and Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) . It's not clear if you would actually get these infections. Your doctor can make sure you are tested in case you have any symptoms such as, fever, chills, aches, stomach pain, diarrhea, pain when you urinate, or being very tired. Make sure you tell your doctor if you get sick or have been sick for a while before you start Stelara.

carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

carousel_items: Don't use alcohol, NSAIDs (anti-inflammatory medications), or stay in the sun too long.
Use birth control and avoid pregnancy for at least 2 months (for women) and 3 months (for men) after you finish Methotrexate.
Drink plenty of liquids to stay hydrated while taking this.
Take the medication exactly as your doctor or pharmacist tells you. Call your doctor or pharmacist if you're confused.

basics.benefits_moa: Methotrexate is an anti-cancer and immunosuppressive medication that treats forms of cancer, arthritis, and psoriasis. For cancer, it helps your body destroy cancer cells by blocking building blocks that cancer cells need to grow. For rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis, it lowers the body's normal immune response and prevents the body from attacking itself.
basics.bottom_line: Methotrexate is a first line treatment for many autoimmune diseases and types of cancer. If you're taking it for a long time, you'll have to get routine blood tests.
downsides: You have to be on birth control for at least 2 to 3 months after you finish Methotrexate since it can cause birth defects.
You have to avoid alcohol and being in the sun too long.
You'll have to get blood tests done if you're taking this long-term because it can cause harmful side effects.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to be on birth control for at least 2 to 3 months after you finish Methotrexate since it can cause birth defects.

You'll have to get blood tests done if you're taking this long-term because it can cause harmful side effects.

upsides: Recommended as first line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis.
Available as a generic medication. Comes as a tablet, an injection that you give yourself weekly, and as an infusion that you get in your doctor's office or at an infusion center.
If you accidentally take too much, there's an antidote to help your body recover.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Talk to your doctor if you are planning to have a baby or are pregnant. Methotrexate can cause birth defects, including death. You or your partner will need to be on birth control for at least 2 to 3 months after you finish Methotrexate to lower this risk.

description_processed.orig: Talk to your doctor if you are planning to have a baby or are pregnant. Methotrexate can cause birth defects, including death. You or your partner will need to be on birth control for at least 2 to 3 months after you finish Methotrexate to lower this risk.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: If you're taking Methotrexate, you’ll need to have your blood checked to avoid toxic effects (blood cells, platelets, liver enzymes, kidney function) and chest X-rays when you start and every 1 to 2 months during treatment. Methotrexate can also cause malignant lymphoma (cancer of the white blood cells). It can happen when you take low-doses of Methotrexate.

description_processed.orig: If you're taking Methotrexate, you’ll need to have your blood checked to avoid toxic effects (blood cells, platelets, liver enzymes, kidney function) and chest X-rays when you start and every 1 to 2 months during treatment. Methotrexate can also cause malignant lymphoma (cancer of the white blood cells). It can happen when you take low-doses of Methotrexate.

risks_warnings.title: Toxicity
risks_warnings.description: You are at higher risk of having toxic symptoms because of too much Methotrexate in your blood if you have kidney disease, or if you have fluid in the abdomen (ascites) or in the lungs (pleural effusion). Your doctor will monitor your body's reaction to Methotrexate very closely if they decide you need to be on Methotrexate.

risks_warnings.title: Liver disease
risks_warnings.description: If you're on Methotrexate for psoriasis, your doctor will have you to do lab tests to check your liver on a regular basis. Acute sudden changes to the liver have been reported, but this has been rare. Call your doctor if you suddenly have pain in your abdomen, you don't feel like eating, or if your skin or the whites of your eyes become yellow.

risks_warnings.title: Lung disease
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people on Methotrexate who develop lung disease. This is very rare. Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get a dry non-productive cough and you don't have a cold or flu.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea | Sores in the mouth
risks_warnings.description: Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get diarrhea or if you get sores in your mouth. This could be a sign of too much Methotrexate in your blood, and your doctor may stop the medication or prescribe an antidote.

risks_warnings.title: Skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: People have reported severe skin reactions while on Methotrexate which can require hospitalization, or possibly cause death. Call your doctor immediately if you get a high fever and a sudden blistering skin rash.

description_processed.orig: People have reported severe skin reactions while on Methotrexate which can require hospitalization, or possibly cause death. Call your doctor immediately if you get a high fever and a sudden blistering skin rash.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tumor lysis syndrome happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Methotrexate to treat cancer, your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Remember you are  a whole person -- focus on mental, physical, emotional, etc. Nutrition response testing, VSL3 (probiotic), eliminate food triggers, mind-body stress reduction... do your own research!

surveys.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
surveys.tip: Nutrition Response Testing & Mind-Body Stress Reduction Exercises

surveys.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Take your diet very seriously.  Understand what triggers flares by keeping a food diary and consider an elimination diet.  Reducing/eliminating gluten (wheat, oats, etc.) and dairy can have a significant impact.  The Paleo Diet, particularly the Anti-Inflammatory Paleo Diet, might be worth considering.  Supplements can also be important, particularly Vitamin D, Folic Acid and B12.  Other supplements worth considering include Alpha Lipoic Acid (ALA), Conjugated Linoleic Acid (CLA), Vitamin C, concentrated mineral drops, liquid calcium citrate, and more.  Probiotics can be hit or miss.  Typically people with ulcerative colitis benefit more from probiotics than people with Crohn's.  Supplements to boost energy may also be beneficial, such as the supplements used to treat chronic fatigue syndrome.  Get plenty of sleep and reduce stress.  Exercise is also particularly important for imroving health and mood.  Yoga has helped many people too.

surveys.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
surveys.tip: Diet, Supplements, Exercise, Yoga, Stress Reduction
